Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, while the Dutch continue wandering about with complete disregard. The US feels hassled by one extended conversation. Is this because Holland bears a place name that begins with "H", which is itself associated with har

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful at times. The writing and the dialogue is dreadful.
The short subtitles, in Courier News style throughout the movie were even more infuriating than usual because each one felt like a summary rather than an explanation of what I should be seeing or understanding (especially when I didn't understand what I was "seeing").

The opening titles tell us we're at Summerhill School. It's actually at Milton Abbey school in Dorset, and is horrifically inaccurate. The staff are all from Dublin and are really little more than geriatric old boys themselves. We get no sense of kindness or nurturing from them, just sadism.
